title: tims-tales-christmas-conscience
story: THE onset of winter, with the deadly cold and dark, was something John always dreaded.It was at this time he would make the decision to line up for a place for a hostel bed.John was homeless and he usually slept rough. Hersquod not always been homeless, of course, but people rarely see the person behind the label.The one good thing about winter for him was the approach of Christmas. Peoplersquos consciences seemed to be more sensitive at Christmas time.He was an alcoholic and he blamed himself every day for what he was. But this just fed his sense of worthlessness and kept the cycle going. His earlier le, the lsquonormal onersquo with his we and children, was now a long time ago, but when he slumbered he often re-entered it in his dreams.Especially that last family Christmas, when they were all together. He would re-run that time in his mind, just like his we would watch The Devil Wears Prada over and over and never tire of it. Yes, when he closed his eyes it could seem he was there again.But when he came to his senses, he came back to himself: an unloved man, old before his time, who people ignored and passed in the street without looking at. He usually felt completely invisible. To be fair, some people did stop and talk, usually the same ones.Perhaps they never truly understood just how valued those moments were.He understood it, after all he despised himself, so how could he expect others to feel dferently.Alcohol seemed to be his one real friend, the only one to understand and ease his pain.But St Andrewrsquos Day was approaching and this was his cue to get completely sober.He would feel that tingle inside that people call lsquofeeling Christmassyrsquo. It was a painful, bittersweet emotion for John, and his friend alcohol always offered to help. But he would close his eyes and be strong.It was the one thing in his le where he felt he had not let people down.So he would summon all his strength and draw on who he used to be for those last vestiges of self-belief and refuse the offer of help from his destructive friend.He made it and arrived at the door of the managerrsquos office, clean, sober and ready to work.The manager had no idea John was the same man he passed on a daily basis on the street outside.Admittedly, he did look dferent now, butthe manager had ever paused to look at John or speak to him, then he would surely recognise him. But for once he was glad of his invisibility. If the manager had ever recognised him outside then John would probably lose his job.ldquoYour costume is in the back room. You start in  minutes, said the manager.ldquoThe paperwork came through last week so yoursquore set to go.John knew the routine and got changed.When he sat in his chair, he was transformed. He was Santa.For the next five weeks, he knew he was going to be noticed and even loved. People would speak to him in a kind and almost reverent way, ask him how he was. His beard and red suit wiped away his sense of worthlessness.All that day, families came and he spoke to more people in that one day being Santa than he did the rest of the year being himself.Afterwards, he headed back to the hostel with money in his pocket.His old friend whispered in his ear: ldquoSpend it on me, spend it on me.ldquoMaybe later, but not now, John replied in his head.But the hostel was full and he couldnrsquot find any other place.And so he knew hersquod have to spend a bitter night on the streets.The food van would arrive soon, so he decided to wait for it in the busy centre.As he sat, a young girl came up to him.She just stood and stared. John recognised her.She had been one of the children in his grotto earlier and suddenly a fear gripped him: she might recognise who he really was.ldquoCome away from there, shouted her mother.But the girl still stood, staring at John. Then she smiled. John smiled back.Her father came up and took her by the hand, pulling her away without looking at John.He recognised the father as well.He had been so nice and friendly in the grotto, while his daughter stood with him for a photo.But without his white beard and red suit, John was invisible again.ldquoSpend it on me, spend on me, whispered his old friend again, as John had flashbacks of Afghanistan.ldquoSpend it on me and I will keep you company, nobody  cares, pleaded his friend.Then the girl was in front of him again, smiling.ldquoThis is for you, Merry Christmas when it comes.Her father stood by her, holding her hand, but still not looking at John.It was chocolate. The same chocolate bar shersquod chosen with glee in the grotto.ldquoThank you, said John and the girl left with her dad.Johnrsquos old friend was now silent. The food van arrived and he packed the chocolate under his jacket. It was more than chocolate.Now he had to get through the freezing night.Tomorrow, hersquod be loved again.

story: HAPPY St Andrewrsquos Day! The results of a poll on peoplersquos favourite Scots word by Scottish Book Trust was revealed this week.So herersquos a tale that includes all the top  favourite Scots words identied in the poll, plus some mair:THE weather matched the young wersquos mood: dreich.By the time she reached the witchrsquos cottage at the foothills of the Lammermuirs, she was soaked.ldquoOch, come in hen, ye look drookit, said the old woman sympathetically. They sat by the fire together.ldquoNoo how can I help ye  asked the old woman.The young we sighed.ldquoI just cannae thole it onymair, she said, getting upset.The old woman listened, waiting for the young woman to compose herself.ldquoItrsquos ma mither-in-law, she bides wi us and, weel, shersquos makin ma le a misery.ldquoHow sae  asked the old woman.ldquoI can dae naethin richt accordin tae her ma cookin is awfu, my hoose is mingin, I canne gie an opinion aboot onythin withoot her sayin the opposite, she treats me asIrsquom glaikit. Irsquom totally scunnerd wi it.ldquoI see, said the witch, ldquoand how can I help ye wi this ldquoI want her oot ma le, I want her deid.ldquoDeid  The witch seemed genuinely shocked.ldquoAye, deid, gone, awa. I just want her oot ma hoose and oot ma le.ldquoWeel, she doenae hae tae be deid fir that, suggested the witch.ldquoAye she does, I dinnae want her aroond. Shersquoll come knocking oan the door. Please can ye help me. I want her deid... er, wi oot it, ye ken, weel sae it isnae murder.ldquoBut it wud be murder ma dear.The young woman bent her head low and began to whisper assomeone might overhear their conversation.ldquoI ken, but ye are a witch, abody says ye hae potions fir onything. Please, I have siller. Mak it look natural. Then me an ma husband can get oan wi oor lives thegither.The witch thought for a moment, then nodded her head.ldquoVery weel, I will help ye, but ye maun dae whit I say.The we smiled with relief: ldquoThank ye.The old woman went ben the hoose to where she kept her herbs and ingredients. The young woman was curious and tried to sneak a look but the witch told her to stay by the fireside until she was finished.Then she came through holding a small bottle of potion.ldquoHere, she said to the we. ldquoThis will dae the trick. Ye maun put ane sma drap o this potion in yer mither-in-lawrsquos tea every day.ldquoBut she maks her ain tea, said the young woman, ldquoshe ay complains I cannae mak tea the proper way.ldquoWeel, ye maun find a way fir her tae allow ye tae mak her tea, said the witch. ldquoThen every day sit wi her as she drinks the tea. She maun drink it a.The we smiled: ldquoHow lang will it tak ldquoOch, mebbes twa months, ye maun use up the hale bottle. Then it will tak effect a few days ater the last drap has been drunk.ldquoTwa months!ldquoAye hen, it must be gradual, otherwise folk will suspect.The young woman clutched the bottle and nodded.ldquoNoo can I hae the siller, asked the witch, and the we willingly paid.ldquoMind tae gie the bottle a wee shoogle afore ye yaise it, the witch advised, ldquoand hud yer wheesht aboot this, or wersquoll baith hang.ldquoO course, said the young woman as she left the witchrsquos house.The weather had lted, as had her mood. Soon her problems would be over, she thought to herself.The witch watched her go, then closed the door. She had a knowing grin on her face.Two months later there was a desperate knocking on the old womanrsquos door. She looked out of the window and saw the young we standing just outwith the cottage, in a terrible state.So she opened her door.ldquoPlease, please help me, begged the young woman.The witch took her inside. The young woman had run all the way and her shawl had become wrapped round her hair, and her dress was dishevelled with the wind.ldquoOch hen, ye are in a richt fankle, sort yersel oot and sit by the fire fir a warm.The young we rearranged her clothes and started to greet as she spoke.ldquoHae ye got an antidote fir the potion please say ye huv, she said.ldquoAn antidote, hen ldquoAye, Irsquove changed ma mind. I gied ma mither-in-law a cup of tea wi the last drap o potion. I watched her drink and then she telt me that I mak a braw cup of tea and that she wis glad her son hud marrit me! It wis in that moment I realised I didnae want her deid!ldquoI see, said the witch. ldquoIrsquom afraid there is nae antidote fir the potion.The young women cradled her head in her hands. ldquoWhit huv I done, what huv I done, she cried to herself.ldquoYe huv got tae ken her, thatrsquos whit yersquove done, said the witch. ldquoAs ye spent time wi her making sure she drank her tea, ye will have talked, am I richt ldquoAye, sobbed the we, ldquoand she listened tae. I ken shersquos an auld witch sometime, er nae offence, but I understand her better noo.The witch smiled. ldquoGuid, she said, ldquonoo ye can gang hame and keep oan huvin the tea thegither, without the potion.ldquoBut shersquos goanie be deid in a few days, sobbed the we.ldquoNaw she isnae, replied the witch, ldquothe potion wis just a few herbs that wouldnae hairm even a wee beastie.ldquoWhat  Ye telt me that it would kill her! protested the we.ldquoNo I didnae, I said it would work ater twa months. And it has. It wis the hatred ye hud that needed kilt, no yer mither-in-law. And the same goes fir her.The young we was so relieved. For a moment she wondered about asking for her money back, but she realised the potion had indeed done its job.Her relationship with her mother-in-law was not always easy, but they had regular cups of tea and chats together, and often they would laugh as they shared memories and stories from le.ldquoThe claes are in a richt bumfle, said the mother-in-law the following day, then she smiled. ldquoBut letrsquos hae oor tea first and we can sort the claes thegither.The we thought to herself that the witch was indeed a wise woman.

title: weekends-christmas-lights-switch-ons-east-lothian
story: Tomorrow , those in Elphinstone can head along to the switch-on at pm.Hot chocolate and mince pies will be served, with people invited to the minersrsquo club afterwards.On Saturday it is North Berwickrsquos turn, with carol singing from pm outside Abbey Church marking the start of the countdown.The light switch-on takes place at .pm, just before Santa arrives, and children have a chance to meet the special guest. Refreshments will be served in the church hall from .pm.On the same day, Prestonpans has a fair in the Town Hall from pm. The lights are switched on at .pm at the war memorial.On Sunday, Cockenzie and Port Seton sees a change of venue. The lights will be switched on this year at the Port Seton Centre at pm.Afterwards, the centre has mulled wine, mince pies, childrenrsquos snacks, activities, a visit from Santa and songs from the community choir.Haddington also switches on its lights on Sunday at the Christmas tree outside the Corn Exchange at .pm. There is also carol singing around the tree assisted by Santa.Also in Haddington, for the first time ever, Nungate Gala Committee has put up a Christmas tree outside Nungate and Haddington Community Centre. Lights will be switched on at .pm, with entertainment, including the chance to visit Santarsquos Grotto, from pm to pm.Musselburgh joins in on the festive fun with theof Santarsquos grotto at this yearrsquos Christmas market, which has been organised by the townrsquos community council.The market runs .am-.pm outside the Old Town Hall, with East Coast Radio and an array of stalls keeping Santa company.The event is followed by the torchlight parade, which leaves the Town Hall at pm. It will be led by The Toun Band, Santa, members of Musselburghrsquos cadet forces, pipe bands and the Clark Community Choir.The parade makes its way to The Brunton for a short carol service and the turning on of the lights at about .pm, which this year will be done by the cast of The Brunton panto Cinderella.Finally on Monday, Ormiston is full of festive cheer. The lights will be switched on at pm in the church car park by Jim Watson, owner of McNeills Garage, and his we Joyce, who will start the countdown.They will be joined by Sandy and Suzanne Butler, who will once again lead the singalong, with help from the school choir and brass band.

title: community-kitchen-looks-raise-3-000-festive-raffle
story: Our Community Kitchen is looking to raise pound, through an lsquoOCKtasticrsquo Christmas raffle, with more than  prizes up for grabs.The fundraiser was launched at a special event earlier this month where volunteers at the good cause welcomed volunteers from community groups including Blooming Haddington, Friends of the River Tyne and Haddington Pipe Band.Elaine Gale, who leads the group, which meets each Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday in Haddington Bowling Club, said: ldquoOur Community Kitchen exists to reduce social isolation and loneliness for people of all ages and abilities in Haddington and the Lammermuir area.ldquoWe use food as a tool to bring people round the table to enjoy each otherrsquos company and make friends.Meals on offer range from sweet and sour chicken with rice followed by sticky toffee pudding, to pulled pork burgers and chips, with lemon puddle pudding for dessert.Miss Gale highlighted the grouprsquos strong links with the community.Earlier this year, the Walk with Scott Foundation, which was formed by Tranent fundraiser Scott Glynn, donated pound, after being impressed by his work.Miss Gale said: ldquoPeople are wanting to get involved and feel like it is their own.Last month, the group, which serves up a three-course meal for pound to an average of  people a week, secured pound, from The National Lottery Community Fund.The money is to be used to pay for the staff team for the next three years.The volunteers are looking to add to that through a series of events to raise money for anything from buying ingredients and subsidising the cost of meals to hiring entertainment or buying birthday cakes for regular visitors.Linda Mitchell, voluntary fundraiser, encouraged people to buy raffle tickets ahead of the draw on December .She said: ldquoThe prizes for our raffle have not only been donated by our great businesses in the town but our own Our Community Kitchen guests have also donated.ldquoThe prizes, which range in value from pound to pound, can be won by buying a ticket for pound.Tickets are available from Joe Forte Sports, Haddington Wines  Whiskies, Pear Tree Nursery and any other business displaying the poster.

title: north-berwick-high-school-pupils-win-3-000-boost-good-cause
story: The pupils won their schoolrsquos Young Philanthropist Initiativecompetition, which saw them researching a social issue and delivering a presentation on it, with the best presentation receiving a pound, grant.The four pupils ndash Mairi Johnston, Jamila Sode-Woodhead, Kristina Grant and Emilee Large ndash donated their prize money to Muirfield Riding Therapy, where two of the group volunteer at a Friday childrenrsquos session.Their presentation was about the West Fenton-based charity, which offers horse riding therapy to children and adults with ious disabilities.Kristina said: ldquoThe highlight of the YPI course was the final round ndash winning the prize money for our charity made me feel very accomplished and as though I could make a real dference for the community and those who use the charity.ldquoI think schools should educate students more on disabilities and how they can help those who have them in everyday le. Businesses should also be encouraged to try and make their buildings and products more disability friendly.ldquoNot only would this help those with disabilities with shopping and other activities but it would increase their customer numbers.Duncan Binnie, religious, moral and philosophical studies teacher at the school and the schoolrsquos YPI lead teacher, said: ldquoThe YPI provides an excellent opportunity for pupils to engagewith their local community in a meaningful and constructive way.ldquoBy interactingdirectly with grassroots charities, pupils develop important communication skills as well as share information about the valuable work these organisations aredoing, often with little funding or resources.ldquoAs a school we have heard from last yearrsquos winners ,who are continuing to move from strength to strength and are very grateful for the pound, funding that last yearrsquos S winners managed to secure.ldquoMuirfield Riding Therapy is another example of a fantastic organisationcommitted to invaluable work within our community. To have a group of our own pupils campaign successfully within the school and to win important funding for them is a real credit to themselves and the school!ldquoA big well done to all the effort that has gone into this yearrsquos project across S and thanks to our  of judges: depute headteacher Robert Jones, our head boy and head girl, and Roy Symon from North Berwick Rotary Club.Susan Law, service co-ordinator at Muirfield Riding Therapy and coach at the session the girls volunteer at, said: ldquoItrsquos brilliant. We have had groups of children apply for YPI funding before but they have not been successful this time they have been.ldquoTwo of the group volunteers for us, they are committed and really work hard. They are passionate about the work we do and always go the extra mile.Most of the money will be spent on a new dementia cafe, with the rest invested in new hygienic toys and storage for the childrenrsquos session.

title: musselburgh-racecourse-meeting-abandoned-due-frozen-track

title: new-learning-hub-now-open-scottish-seabird-centre
story: The team have been working in partnership with Glasgow Science Centre for  months to transform all aspects of the five-star visitor experience and educational resources at the centre, which will reopen completely on Saturday  December followed by a formal launch in January.The learning hub will provide a more engaging and flexible space for inspiring and educating visiting schools, youth and further education groups.The new look learning hub and marine workshops are now available to book and it continues to be used by the charityrsquos weekly wildle watch groups, which are supported by the Scottish Wildle Trust.All of the furniture from the old education classroom has been given to Zero Waste Dunbar, a non-profit social enterprise which aims to keep good things in local circulation, rather than sending them to landfill.Launching the new hub, with young people from the centrersquos Wildle Watch Group, Provost, John McMillan said ldquoThe Scottish Seabird Centre has been a key part of East Lothianrsquos tourism and education offering for nearly  years. The new learning hub offers a high quality and flexible space that can be used by both East Lothian schools and residents, and those from further afield.Susan Davies, CEO of the Scottish Seabird Centre, added: ldquoScotlandrsquos marine environment is exceptional and erse. There is a growing awareness of both its importance and the pressures it is under ndash not least from the climate crisis, invasive non-native species, underwater noise and marine pollution. Our new learning hub will help us deliver on our purpose to inspire and educate people about Scotlandrsquos marine environment.Following the launch of the learning hub, the final space to be completed is the discovery experience, an interactive visitor experience which will enable people to learn more about Scotlandrsquos marine habitats and wildle, and use the interactive live cameras to watch seasonal wildle on the Firth of Forth islands. The formal launch in January will coincide with the start of Scotlandrsquos Year of Coasts and Waters.

title: walk-scott-ball-raises-9000-projects
story: The lsquoScotters Ballrsquo took place at Royal Musselburgh Golf Club on November .It was hailed a huge success by the Tranent-based foundation, which said it raised about pound, for local causes and projects.Alex Hodgson and the Last Resort provided music, there was a special screening of the Walk With Scott Foundationrsquos new film about the work and history of the charity and also a raffle and an auction. Included in the auction were signed gloves by world champion boxer Josh Taylor and among the prizes were holidays and also a cooked and delivered Christmas dinner for .Karen Kidd, who helps run the foundation, said: ldquoIt was a fab night. We sold a lot of tickets to Scotters and sponsors, and everyone got dressed up and they all looked great.ldquoScott was able to attend and he even spoke for quite a while and chatted to people. It was great ndash it just means everything that he was there.ldquoWe alsohad the good news lastTuesday [November]that his son Gareth had a baby girl.

title: bay-city-rollers-star-saves-dog-stuck-hole-two-days
story: Bay City Rollers guitarist Stuart lsquoWoodyrsquo Wood was to prove the hero after Kruger, a -year-old black Labrador, went missing on Sunday, November , at about pm.Kruger was on his regular evening walk with owner Janette Murray, , of North Berwickrsquos Rhodes Park, next to the former East Lothian Council depot at Lime Grove.But after going to investigate a scent, he did notwhen called.Janettersquos daughter, -year-old Donna Denton, of the townrsquos Couper Avenue, told the Courier: ldquoHe is a rehomed dog, my mum got him when he was three.ldquoHe is quite timid but very, very friendly and doesnrsquot growl or bark at people ndash I have two kids and hersquos great with them.ldquoIf he does wander off he comes back as soon as he canrsquot see you, he always stays very close.ldquoWe now know the reason he didnrsquot come back this time. The lady from search and rescue said dogs donrsquot bark for help, only when they feel threatened.Kruger was found two days later by Bay City Rollers star Wood at about .am on Tuesday ndash the musician, who was on holiday in North Berwick, was one of  looking for the missing dog.He later posted on Facebook to say ldquothanks for the lovely messages and praising everyone who ldquosearched relentlessly.ldquoWell done everyone ndash we got lucky! he added.The terried dog was eventually found just metres from where he went missing.People all over North Berwick had helped in the search, not realising that Kruger was so close by.One man checked every bunker on the  holes at nearby Glen Golf Club ndashcounting  in total.Kruger gained access to the derelict Lime Grove site through a broken fence.Donna, a childminder and registered nurse, said: ldquoThe hole he fell down was no bigger than  centimetres by  centimetres, he couldnrsquot even lie down in it and was sitting up the whole time he was down there. We couldnrsquot even get our feet in there to help lt him out.ldquoWe phoned the fire brigade as we didnrsquot know what to do but my husband ended up putting a hoist around him and, with another manrsquos help, lting Kruger out with brute force.And she added: ldquoThe area he was found in is such a state and an absolute junkyard ndash therersquos broken bins and slabs everywhere, graffiti etc. It is not safe and is not secure.During the search, Donna contacted the police, SSPCA, search and rescue, the council and Edinburgh Dog and Cat Home, though she said she ldquocouldnrsquot get through to the dog warden at the council.After being rescued and wrapped up in blankets, Kruger was then sent to the vets for a check-up.Donna added: ldquoA man from the council had keys to the gate at the site and let me reverse my car in so I could put Kruger in the back.ldquo[Kruger] was really stf, so we had to carry him into the car and into the vets.ldquoHe was put on some fluids but my mum was able to get him home later that night luckily he wasnrsquot hurt.An appeal to find Kruger posted on social media attracted plenty of attention, something Donna was not expecting.She was full of praise for everyone who helped out, saying: ldquoEveryone was amazing. I had people I didnrsquot know come up to me at the school gates saying they were going to look for Kruger. We were just so lucky it was two mild nights when he was down there.ldquoMy mum will be  next year but was out all day trying to look for him, she didnrsquot want to stop or turn back. She was determined to find him.Since the incident, the hole has been covered with a slab, but the fence still remains damaged.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoIf anyone is aware of an uncovered manhole then itrsquos recommended that they report the exact location to the council, who will investigate further to make it safe.ldquoThis can be done online or via our out of hours number:  .

title: new-musselburgh-bar-gets-go-ahead
story: The Musselburgh Bar and Kitchen, formerly the Mexican restaurant Habaneros on High Street, was granted a iation of premises licence by East Lothian Councilrsquos licensing board last week.Owner Star Pubs  Bars had applied for: extension of opening hours from midnight to am on a Thursday use of premises for clubs and group meetings an outdoor drinking area changes both internally to the building to re-position bar and seating areas and extension of the rear drinking smoking area outside.A number of objections centred around concerns of possible noise disturbance and smoke from the outdoor area.The board heard that the outdoor smoking area would be moved from its present location away from neighbouring properties and that this area would also be covered by CCTV.Members of the licensing board agreed to grant permission with conditions. They included that children and young people under  could only be on the premises after pmthey were having a meal or attending a private, pre-arranged , and that CCTV was operational both within and outside the building.In addition, the beer garden would close at pm and an entertainment licence was not granted so no recorded or live music could be played outside.The new bar had previously received planning permission.A spokesperson for Star Pubs  Bars said the premises would be turned into ldquoa modern premium bar.She said it was hoped that a new licensee would take on the venture, which would offer food throughout the day and alfresco dining.She said the proposed investment followed another recent refurbishment project involving Star Pubs  Bars at The Seaglass Inn, Port Seton, previously the Wemyss Hotel.

title: general-election-candidates-lock-horns-hustings
story: The event ndash at St Andrew Blackadder Church ndash saw the candidates answering questions submitted by the public ahead of the election next Thursday.Organised by North Berwick and District Association of Churches, it was chaired by Keith Stewart QC.Labourrsquos Martin Whitfield began by saying that serving as MP for the last two years had been a pleasure and a privilege.He also said: ldquoI am the only pro-Union person sitting on this  that can win here, which Conservative candidate Craig Hoy was quick to disagree with.David Sisson, UKIP, used a cookie jar analogy to make his partyrsquos position on Brexit clear saying: ldquoThe cookies belong to us. Itrsquos time we get them back and we can work out how we split them up once we have them back.Answering a question on how to tackle climate change Robert OrsquoRiordan, Liberal Democrats, said: ldquoI think that one of the best ways is to stay within the EU.The SNPrsquos candidate Kenny MacAskill said the country needed to disinvest in fossil fuels.The next question asked candidatesthey thought there ought to be a  per cent majority threshold on referendums.Mr MacAskill said he didnrsquot, adding: ldquoPeople werenrsquot voting for a no deal Brexit, that was never put forward. I agree that the majority prevails, but I think we have to realise thatyou win by one the winner canrsquot have all.Mr Hoy said he would agree there should be a threshold in future elections.He added: ldquoI understand why Kenny doesnrsquot support it because the SNP can barely secure  per cent, never mind  per cent, for independence.Candidates were then asked why they should be trusted by the public.Mr Sisson took this opportunity to point out that he wasnrsquot a politician and he was standing because he felt it was the right thing to do.Mr Whitfield suggested constituents believe those who did what they said they would do, adding: ldquoI think the Government breaking the law and having to be told by the Supreme Court that they have broken the law severely undermines the trust in politicians.Next, with Russia raised as a potential threat, candidates were asked about defence spending.MacAskill thought the defence budget should not change, saying: ldquoThe dficulty that faces our military is that everything is being put into nuclear weapons and Trident. I do not believe in Trident, I do not believe in nuclear weapons.Mr Sisson questioned the British Armyrsquos future as ldquoBritish defence more and more seems to be integrated into European forces.Mr Hoy said the Conservatives would increase expenditure on defence by . per cent above the rate of inflation. He added: ldquoTrident makes us safer.Mr Whitfield said: ldquoThere is a commitment from a Labour government to maintain its position in NATO and the two per cent. There is a commitment to renew Trident.Mr OrsquoRiordan also said he would maintain the two per cent GDP target, adding: ldquoIrsquom not sure of the nature of the Russian threat ndash I think it is much more to do with cyberspace and the threat to our democracy.ldquoAs we know, Boris Johnson has a dossier on his desk which he hasnrsquot released that talks about Russian intervention in the European referendum and in the European elections.Question then focused on healing the isions from Brexit, Islamophobia, and anti-Semitism in politics.Mr Hoy said he thought ldquothe issue of accountability in politics is extremely important, adding that, on comments made by Boris Johnson mocking Muslim womenrsquos appearance, he thought ldquothe Prime Minister should be held to the same account for any particular phrases that he uses but ldquothat would be for him to comment on.Mr Whitfield said he believed the Labour Party should apologise to the Jewish community for its handling of complaints of anti-Semitism in the party.He added: ldquoWith regard to what happens to bring society together widely, I think a referendum or confirmatory vote would allow people to discuss and debate and then to express their feelings through ballot box.Mr MacAskill called for better education and more enforcement, adding: ldquoYou cannot just whip up hatred and say what you like.Lastly, the candidates were asked what three things they had done for East Lothian.Mr Hoy mentioned implementing the Change and Check breast cancer campaign, voting for East Lothian Councilrsquos emergency climate change declaration, and working with police to tackle anti-social behaviour and drug use in the county.Mr Whitfield highlighted helping people with Universal Credit payments, taking county art therapy charity The Teapot Trust to Westminster and, in his previous job as a primary school teacher, teaching children in East Lothian who he had now seen getting jobs and apprenticeships.Mr OrsquoRiordan listed his involvement in setting up the hustings and working with church groups, working towards achieving the Drem-Gullane path, and convening East Lothian Liberal Democrats.Mr MacAskill cited, in his time as Justice Secretary, establishing the CashBack for Communities scheme, helping implement minimum alcohol pricing, and reducing youth offending.Mr Sisson answered by describing his work as an electrician for the council, choosing to stand as an MP, and his involvement with Musselburgh Amateur Musical Association.When asked to sing the last line of his answer by the chair, the UKIP candidate obliged, belting out to the filled church that he hoped to deliver democratic freedom to constituents.

title: bid-build-new-hotel-replace-gullanes-mallard
story: Gullanersquos The Mallard Hotel has been run by the same family for more than half a century but new plans reveal a dramatic change for the East Links Road venue.Information boards were on display in the hotel last Thursday afternoon before a presentation was given to the villagersquos community council.Currently, the hotel is made up of  bedrooms, with a bar, bistro and garden room open to the public.However, the proposed new hotel ndash which would be built over three floors ndash would include  bedrooms, as well as a restaurant, lounge and spa facilities.Structured House Group is behind the plans, with a formal planning application expected to be with East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department before the end of the year.Hotel owners Cameron and Susan Law intend to step down from the business, which has been in the family for  years,the proposals are given the green light.Susan, who is also chairman of Muirfield Riding Therapy, which offers free horse-riding for people with disabilities, stressed that The Mallard Hotel remained open for business as usual and would continue to be so for the foreseeable future.She told the Courier: ldquoI think, initially, I was quite shocked that it was going to be knocked down but in retrospect it is the best thing really.ldquoObviously, we will be sad to see it go but we will take The Mallard Hotel with us is how I am thinking now. It is very dear to us.About  people attended the public exhibition in the hotel and Tony Thomas, representing the developers, was pleased with how the six-hour drop-in event had gone.He said: ldquoIt was overwhelmingly positive ndash mainly because it is not housing [being proposed].ldquoThe vast majority of people really, really like the design. The only slight hiccup was two or three immediate neighbours were concerned over parking so we will look at that. If there is not enough parking, it spills out onto the street.Tom Drysdale, chairman of Gullane Area Community Council, was at the presentation and the meeting afterwards.He said there were concerns about the proposals and noted residentsrsquo worries about parking and traffic generated by the new hotel.Mr Drysdale said: ldquoThe plans were well presented.ldquoWhat they are proposing is a fine installation and it looks as though it would be a good, upmarket, modern hotel with good facilities.ldquoThere is considerable concern in the community about the problems likely to arise from car parking.ldquoThat was the big issue in the discussions at the community council meeting.ldquoThere were a lot of people indicating signicant concern on that point. It is quite a heavily built-up residential area and already the parking is under pressure from residents.ldquoI would say the new hotel has signicantly more rooms than the present one. It is also supposedly going to have an upmarket restaurant, which will attract evening customers.

title: busy-a198-near-tranent-closed-several-evenings
story: There will be a full overnight closure of the A between the two roundabouts at the Bankton Junction. Drivers wanting to cross the bridge which travels over the A, linking Tranent to Prestonpans and Cockenzie and Port Seton, will face a y ersion.Joining and exiting the A at the junction will still be possible.From Monday until next Saturday , ldquoessential expansion joint replacement works will be carried out between the hours of pm and am each night.Closure of the bridge footpaths will also be required while the work is under way.Pedestrians, cyclists, and motorcycles under cc looking to cross the bridge will be marshalled safely across by the on-site team.A southbound traffic will be erted to take the first exit at the roundabout to join the A in an easterly direction towards Gladsmuir Junction.Traffic will be directed to take the exit at Gladsmuir Junction and, at the roundabout, will take the third exit onto the B.At the following roundabout, traffic will take the third exit to join the A but in a westerly direction towards Bankton Junction.From there, traffic will exit at Bankton Junction and take the second exit at the roundabout to rejoin the A.Meanwhile, A northbound traffic will be erted to take the first exit at the roundabout to join the A westbound.Traffic will proceed towards Dolphingstone and will exit at the next junction.From there, traffic will then take a right turn onto the A, crossing the A and will take a further right turn to rejoin the eastbound carriageway of the A.Traffic will follow this route to take the exit at Bankton Junction and at the roundabout will take the first exit to rejoin the A.All works are weather dependent and may be cancelled or rescheduledweather conditions are not favourable.This scheme has been planned in consultation with Transport Scotland, Traffic Scotland, the emergency services and East Lothian Council.

title: rugby-players-tackle-giant-jenners-xmas-tree
story: This yearrsquos tree is a ft-high Norway spruce that was grown in Stirling. It was supplied by Conox, which has provided Christmas trees for Edinburghrsquos Christmas market and Leicester Square in London.Ross High RFC has helped get the tree in place in Jenners for the past  years, a tradition which started after one former member had a connection to the company K which helps hoist the tree and put on the lights.John Tinlin, Ross High Rugby Club president, said: ldquoThis yearrsquos tree was not as big as it usually is but the guys all know the script.ldquoWe have to take the tree in through the revolving doors at the front of the store since there is no other way to bring it in, so we need to be very careful.ldquoThe doors are actually taken off so there is enough room. It was a tight squeeze but we managed.ldquoIt was well wrapped, which made it a lot easier.Ross High sent a team of  along to help bring the tree into the iconic Princes Street store, with the whole process taking just  minutes.John added: ldquoIt was quicker than usual.The team volunteer their time but are rewarded with pizza by the staff at Jenners.The process is a very Scottish affair, with rugby club members wearing kilts and music performed on bagpipes.Once the tree is brought in, staff from K abseil from the roof, helping to hoist it up and put the lights on ndash a process which takes place overnight.The lights were turned on by five-year-old Chloe from Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital, who won the opportunity through a charity auction.Following reports that Jenners might leave Princes Street and moving to another city centre location, John added: ldquoHopefully the tradition goes ahead again next year as we have been a part of it for such a long time.

title: Rosemary Goring  More female leaders offers hope of safer  stronger world
story: Within a decade of that declaration,   set the wheels spinning on what promises to become a century or more of exceptional chaos and carnage in the middle east, and far beyond.Everyone can get it wrong, especially those whose closely argued ideas are reduced to soundbites. And so it might yet prove with another of Fukuyamas pronouncements. It is his contention that the developed world has recently become more peaceable thanks to women as heads of state and in positions of political influence.Ive often heard people say there would be less conflict and fewer warswomen were in charge. Usually its the middle-aged and elderly ndash mothers, aunts and grandmothers ndash who make this claim. They have never scaled the heights of a male-dominated industry or profession, yet hope that the women they see in charge are imbued with the same gentle, conciliatory and nurturing personalities as themselves. And there, I would suggest, is the snag.Nor am I being unduly cynical. A study by the University of Chicago covering  years of European historyhas shown that not only were queens more inclined to take their country into battle than kings, but also more certain to win.:Nicola Sturgeon announces funding for women leaders schemeIn Victorias day, Britain was at war with some part of the empire, or would-be empire, almost every year of her reign. Three hundred years earlier, Elizabeth I set a gold standard for empire building, showing her mettle as she fought off Spanish incursions, despatching her own conquistadors across the globe, and managing to maintain stability in a precariously inflammable period of religious stre asshe were refereeing a game of croquet.The leader of the Chicago study, Professor Oeindrila Dube, points out that you need only think of Catherine the Great of Russia, or Isabella I of Castile to appreciate that, in previous centuries, royal women were every bit as war-like as men. When circumstances dictated, they didnrsquot hesitate to shed blood.Quite how they felt privately, of course, is another matter. Henry VIIIs daughter, who earned the title Bloody Mary after condemning almost  Protestants and religious dissenters to the pyre, was apparently a warm and affectionate person. What her notorious actions indicate, perhaps, is less a vengeful nature and more the vicious tenor of her times.Even our own Mary Queen of Scots was no peacenik, riding at the head of her troops on more than one occasion and, far from avoiding conflict, at times seeming actively to court it.Professor Dubersquos analysis of royal authority shows that when a queen was in power, she was even more effective than a man. Since she would often work in partnership with her consort, her subjects were effectively getting two warriors for the price of one. There is, however, a great dference between what was required of female rulers in the reign of Victoria and before, and attitudes in modern times.In almost every era prior to our own Elizabethan age, to be a woman was seen to be weak. Debate raged across Europe in the th century about how worthy and capable females could ever beplaced on a throne. John Knox, enraged at Mary of Guise becoming Regent of Scotland, spoke for many when he declared her appointment ldquoas seemly a sight as to put a saddle upon the back of an unruly cow.Given such hostility, itrsquos entirely possible that it was not the assistance of their husbands that made Boudiccas of high-ranking women, but the need to show that they were every bit as aggressive and dangerous as men. The message needed to be sent that anyone who tried to topple them would live ndash albeit briefly ndash to regret it.Margaret Thatcher thrust us into battle in the Falklands where many other prime ministers might have hesitated. You could see her pugnacity, on this and other inflammatory issues, as the problem with Fukuyamas theory. Women who reach the political pinnacle today have had to fight to get there. These are no ordinary women, these are powerful women. Hilary Clintonrsquos personality surely proves that point: her pitch for the presidency showed her to be a great deal more hawk than dove.:Project aims to help women stand for electionYet Fukuyama ndash and others ndash might nevertheless be right in hoping for a less violent futuremore women are at the top table. Nobody has done more to show Germany in a pacic and positively humanitarian light than Angela Merkel, even though she knew her policies risked her political standing in some quarters.To date, the performance of those like Mary Robinson, when she was Irish president, or Helle Thorning-Schmidt when Denmarkrsquos prime minister, or New Zealandrsquos Jacinda Ardern, not to mention Scotlands first minister, offers reason to hope. The ability to compromise, to use diplomatic means to defuse conflict, or find a way around an impasse is, while by no means solely a female quality, certainly one at which we are beginning to excel.Sweeping generalisation though it is, women are undoubtedly less physically combative and martial than men, though potentially nasty nevertheless. It can be seen as early as the school playground that our preferred weaponry is verbal attack and the ability to work stealthily, in ways of which Machiavelli would approve, to undermine the enemy.Irsquove never believed we are nicer than men ndash my experience has been quite the opposite. Yet in the West at least, attitudes in government and society are changing. Itrsquos now possible to be feminine and command respect. Gender no longer signals deficiency. Increasingly, even, it could be seen as a positive advantage.Growing numbers of women are rising through the democratic ranks on the strength of their strategic and negotiating skills, rather than their gung-ho, macho credentials. As a new generation is attracted to these roles, seeing that they no longer need to act tough in order to succeed, then things might just improve. Perhaps it is a reasonable assumption after all that, with more female hands at the tiller, nations will become stronger and safer.

title: holding-politicians-account-duty-not-bore
story: Tuesday nightrsquos encounter was not an exact replacement for Kylersquos late and unlamented three ring circus. No-one, as far as I recall, demanded a lie detector test, but had the programme run on past the hour there is no telling where it would have ended up. A brawl in the car park at Pacic Quay perhaps Still, the debate was well worth having,only to produce a sight so rare it is up there with baby pandas and Richard Leonard having a good day on the campaign trail. To wit: Nicola Sturgeon, First Minister of Scotland, being held to account and feeling the heat.: Ferry fiasco as Ministers suedEarlier that day, the results of the  Programme for International Student Assessmentsurvey had been published, and they did not make welcome reading for Scotlandrsquos pupils. Scotlandrsquos educational performance, on which the country has always prided itself ndash rightly or wrongly ndash was revealed to be a dangerously leaning tower. Reading levels were up, but performances in maths and science were falling and at record lows. Lindsay Paterson, professor of education policy at Edinburgh University, described Scotlandrsquos overall performance as ldquostagnating in mediocrity.As well as being taken to task on education, the subject on which she has asked to be judged first and foremost, the First Minister was asked about the state of Scotlandrsquos hospitals."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","description": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media iFShJ poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests iFShJ.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": This was not the first time she had been tackled on the subject on television. There was Andrew Neilrsquos now famous question to her on November  in his BBC show.After stating that only two of eight waiting time targets had been hit, Neil went on: ldquoChildren are dying in a new Glasgow hospital because the water is contaminated, perhaps by pigeon droppings. A new multi-million pound Edinburgh hospital, should have opened in , is still unfit to open. You canrsquot even get the ventilation system to work. Yoursquove got the worst drug addiction problem in Europe but you cut drug treatment budgets by pound million. You clung on to your last health minister, you are under pressure to sack her successor. Yoursquove called for legislation to protect the NHS from Donald Trump. Maybe the NHS needs legislation to protect it from Nicola Sturgeon : Sturgeon acccuses think-tank on analysisIt was a blistering inquiry. To be fair to Ms Sturgeon, she had responses for both Neil last week and her interrogators on Tuesday. To Neil, she pointed out, among other things, the pound million being put into meeting waiting time targets, the public inquiry into the Royal Hospital for Sick Children in Edinburgh, and the ldquoextremely high public satisfaction ratings for the NHS in Scotland. In the STV debate she highlighted the improvement in reading.The question here is not how she performed in both instances. She is an impressive politician, on the national and international stage. But why does it take a General Election for her to be challenged so robustly  Why are there not more such encounters For all Andrew Neilrsquos talents, he did not fall out of a magic interviewer tree. He is smart, fast, has a certain dogged style and command of facts and puts them to good use. Similarly, there was nothing radically dferent about the STV debate, other than the participants were allowed to cross examine each other, an innovation all other televised debates should adopt.There is no doubt that the First Minister regularly puts her record forward for scrutiny. She does it every week at FMQs for starters. It should be noted, too, that like the other party leaders, but not Boris Johnson, she went into the Neil den. He has been frit she was not. Over the past few weeks she has appeared in countless debates and phone-ins.Yet as far as television grillings go, it is only in the Neil interview and the STV debate that she has been robustly held to account.Granted, the notion that Scotlandrsquos First Minister is somehow given an easy ride will be laughable to some. Of the near dozen national daily newspapers in Scotland only one, our sister paper The National, openly backs independence and, by implication, the main party supporting it.Of the rest, as any visit to the newsagents will show, no-one would suspect them of being cheerleaders for the FM, and some are ferocious in their criticism.As for the BBC in Scotland, it comes under frequent attack for alleged bias, a charge it denies.This is not solely about the media, however. It is about a political culture that has become too settled and not questioning enough.In part the failure to hold the FM and her Ministers to account can be put down to the calibre of opposition politicians. A fair number, not all, are simply not good enough. Nor is the Scottish Parliament always sitting when problems arise.: Candidate leaflet defacedI do not believe that the First Minister is given an easier time of it because she is a woman. If anything, the opposite is true.The trouble goes wider than any branch of the media, or inidual politician. A few months ago there was a dust up on Twitter between Muriel Gray and Val McDermid. The row flared over a tweet by the BBCrsquos political editor Laura Kuenssberg and whether or not it showed bias against the FM. Ms McDermid said: ldquoI used to respect you @bbclaurak. Insulting a politician for doing their job, however, reduces that respect to shreds.To which Ms Gray replied: ldquoMocking politicians of all and every party instead of beatying them used to be the norm in Scotland. We were rather good at it. The bedrock of Scots humour. Not sure I even recognise this lsquoworship the great leader or rsquo thing. Itrsquos so not ...Scottish. And so it went on.Did Gray have a point  Is there enough distance in Scotland between the government and the governed, or after so long with one party in power has the situation become cosier than is good for us Every government makes mistakes. All governments can do better. There have to be ways of pointing that out that donrsquot meet with accusations of bias or unfairness. Criticising a Scottish Government ndash of whatever stripe ndash is not criticising Scotland. We forget that at our peril.

title: helen-mcardle-gps-ever-workload-increasing---appointments-harder-get
story: For the health service toefficiently, general practice must be able to perform its role as gatekeeper: sting the patients whose symptoms require an onward referral for tests, scans or a specialist consultants from those whose ailments are minor and can be tackled through primary care services.This is not easy when GP workload has been soaring while the total number of GPs in Scotland has remained almost static by comparison.READMORE: GPs vote to take back control for hiring practice staffBetween  and , the overall GP headcountgrew by just %, from  to .At the same time, the number of patients registered per GP practice has swelled % and become considerably older, bringing with it an increasing volume of patients living with multiple long-term illnesses.Doctors on the frontline also tell poignant stories of elderly patients who will turn up at their GP surgery several times a week simply because they are lonely and want to talk to someone.For every GP in Scotland today, there are  patients aged  or older - up % from  per GP a decade ago.Measuring GPs by headcount gives an overly optimistic picture compared to the reality on the ground, however.Part-time working has become increasingly common, partly because a majority of the professionnow are women more likely to juggle work with childcare, but also because more GPs are reducing their hours for a better work-le balance.The result is that when the GP workforce is counted by full-time equivalent , there were only , in  . That was a decline from , in , and it is a downward trend expected to continue when the next data set is published in .That translates as an increasing - and increasingly unmanageable - workload for GPs, but also longer waiting times for patients as same-dayappointments become harder and harder to secure.: Jeane Freeman admits mistakes in how new GP contract affected rural practicesWhile the Scottish Government has pledged an extra  GPs by , it has so far refused to commit to that being anything other than an increase in headcount.Meanwhile, statistics this week showed that the number of GP partners in Scotland has fallen to a record low.Partners now account for just % of the GP workforce, compared to % in , increasing the risk that surgeries will run out of GPs to own and run them and will have to close, merge or be taken over by health boards instead .The bedrock of the our NHS is on shaky ground.

title: connect-call-artists-chosen-top-design-fair-revealed
story: Audiences in London are to be given a glimpse of the strength of Scottish design after Craft Scotland unveiled this years submissions to Collect, the international art fair for modern craft and design.Metalwork shaped to resemble ceramics, textiles inspired by the rugged landscapes of their creators homeland and furniture crafted from Perthshire Oak are all among the works of the artists selected for Scotlands showcase at the craft sectors premier event.Textiles form part of the showcaseCraft Scotland will have its own dedicated gallery space displaying covetable artworks in silversmithing, goldsmithing, furniture making, ceramics, weaving and blacksmithing.:Nike unveils specially designed shoes for doctors and nursesSpeaking ahead of the show Craft Scotland Director, Irene Kernan said: ldquoWe are delighted to be ing to Collect in  as with every year the reputation of the Craft Scotland showcase grows."Last year saw signicant acquisitions of Scottish craft by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge and the National Museum of Northern Ireland."We look forward to championing the work of these eight Scotland-based makers whose craft embraces experimental techniques and innovative materials and plays with scale and perceptions of materiality."As well as putting Scottish design on the international stage, the event can also be lucrative for those who take part.Ms Kernan added: "Itrsquos these qualities, married to an ambition to push the boundaries of their work, that makes Scottish craft so highly sought after at events like Collect.:Exhibition devoted to Scotlandrsquos lsquooverlookedrsquo abstract art#"With sales averaging pound, across the four days of the event in recent years we hope the makers will enjoy financial benefits as well as professional ones.Araminta CampbellHeld for the first time in Somerset House in London, Collect brings together galleries, artists and collectors from around the world to display their latest creations. Now in its th year, the even has gone become one of the worlds leading fairs for museum-quality art, and is regarded as one of the highlights of the international craft calendar.Following a rigorous selection process, eight Scottish artists were selected, including Daniel Freyne, a blacksmith who works with iron, and Araminta Campbell of Edinburgh, whose textile work takes inspiration from Scotlandrsquos landscape to create carefully sourced hand-woven pieces.:Bright sparks show the future is in safe hands#Returning artists include silversmithing artist Hamish Dobbie, whose new collection of silver drinking vessels builds on the popular collection featured last year, and master craftsman Angus Ross, who will present new work in steam-bent oak crafted using computer-controlled cutting.Other selected include ceramicists Jonathan Wade, whose sculptures draw inspiration from the natural world, and Mella Shaw, who uses traditional smoke-firing techniques - said to be the most ancient pottery technique - to create innovative designs.Daniel FreyneDesigner Naomi Mcintosh works with wood to create objects ranging from jewellery to sculptural objects to full-blown installations, while jeweller Rhona McCallums geologically-inspired works come fresh from exhibitions at Goldsmithsrsquo Fair in London and The Museum of Arts and Design in New York.Selection list Hugo Macdonald said: ldquoThe eight makers we selected to represent Scotland at Collect  prove that the countryrsquos craft heritage is thriving."These are compelling pieces, from the minds and hands of extremely talented craftspeople. Each of the makers demonstrates impressive skill, creativity and a commitment to quality that deserves a global  and showcase.Fellow list Emma Nicolson added: "Scotland has a wealth of talent in craft and as one of the selection  for this yearrsquos Collect it was really exciting to gain a deeper insight into the range of skill and talent from across Scotland."The artists we selected represent the finest work we have to offer and it great that audiences in London will have the opportunity to experience it first hand."Jessica Bonehill, Creative Industries Officer , Creative Scotland said: ldquoShowcasing Scottish work at Somerset House this year will highlight craft as one of Scotlandrsquos strengths."The ambitious and thoughtful work selected represents the innovative ways makers in Scotland are re-imagining their fields and enriching our understanding of what it means to make craft today.Craft Scotland will showcase at Collect  from Thursday  February to Sunday  March .

title: oil-gas-expansion-makes-mockery-uk-climate-boasts
story: In a list of the  countries with the biggest plans for increased extraction of fossil fuels, the UK is ranked eighth, which the Global Gas and Oil Network , a coalition of environmental charities, said completely undermines any claims the nation is a leader in the fight against climate change.The research analyses planned oil and gas expansion across more than , fields worldwide and concludes that,it goes ahead, global temperatures will rise well above the target of .C that was agreed in the Paris Agreement.It notes that companies are set to invest an additional . trillionin new extraction projects over the next five years, the majority in shale and offshore oil and gas.The report claims carbon emissions from fields and mines operating currently would already push the world beyond . degrees of warming and make it impossible to meet international commitments under the Paris Agreement ndash evencoal use was phased out overnight and emissions from cement production drastically reduced.But every major international oil company has sanctioned new oil or gas projects, or both, which are not compliant with the goals set in Paris.Between them they would ldquolock in carbon emissions until at least .GGON says it has focused on expansion projects within the next five years to emphasise the urgent need to plot a dferent way ahead.It is calling for a planned wind-down of fossil fuel extraction, ensuring plans can be put in place to create a transition to other forms of energy and industries that are socially just and economically sound.High income countries should be ldquofirst movers in this process, it says, while investors should stop financing projects that undermine climate goals.The UKrsquos plans place it ahead of countries such as Nigeria and Brazil, the report says, with plans to open up undeveloped and ldquoundiscovered fields representing more than . billion barrels of oil and gas.The network is supported by Global Witness and  other organisations. Stuart McWilliam, of Global Witness, said: ldquoThese new statistics frankly make a mockery of claims that the UK is a leader in the fight against climate change. Successive UK Governments have not only ignored the role of oil and gas, but ensured we are expanding its production.ldquoThis is simply not compatible with the Paris climate goals to avoid irreversible climate breakdown.ldquoA year from now whoever wins the General Election will hold the presidency of the UNrsquos vital Conference of the Parties climate summit. If the UK is really to lead the world in the battle against climate change, the next Government will need to abandon these expansion plans and instead announce the start of a planned phase-out of fossil fuels.ldquoWe are facing a climate emergency ndash our planet and our country canrsquot afford more dither and delay, otherwise the battle to save the planet could be lost.Worldwide, over the next five years, the oil and gas sector has plans to invest .tn in new fields and methods of extraction.Critics say this would lock companies and countries on a path that will guarantee  gigatonnes of cumulative carbon dioxide emissions, the equivalent of building , new coal-fired power stations.America and Canada are responsible for  per cent of the potential expansion in production, followed by Argentina, Chile, Norway, Australia, Mexico and the UK. Tzeporah Berman, international campaign director at US-based charity Stand.Earth, said: ldquoIf your house is on fire, you donrsquot add more fuel. ldquoNo one is saying turn off the taps overnight. We still use oil and gas today, but we must act now to stop the planned expansion by the oil and gas industry that could lock us into an unsafe climate.Global Witness is calling on the UK Government to phase out all subsidies and tax breaks for oil and gas expansion, legislate to ensure extraction is compatible with the . degree limit to warming agreed by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, and to stop issuing licences for new oil and gas exploration.It also wants to see the repeal of measures in the UKrsquos  Infrastructure Act, which calls on governments to ldquomaximise economic recovery of oil and gas, effectively binding successive administrations to ensure as much oil and gas as possible is extracted.

title: poll-resurgent-snp-set-make-big-gains
story: Nicola Sturgeons party will pick up % of votes on Thursday, a YouGov survey for The Times has found.However, the Tories are predicted to hold eight of their  Scottish seats in a development that might just keep Boris Johnson in Downing Street.That is because the Conservative share of the vote has jumped eight percentage points since YouGov last carried out a poll in August. The UK government party now stands at %, up from % in the summer. The Brexit Party, meanwhile, has lost all of its support in Scotland, dropping from % to zero.:Labour accuse BBC of bias towards ConservativesPolling and politics expert John Curtice, writing in The Times, said: "Much of the Conservative advance is a consequence of the collapse in support for the Brexit Party....the Conservatives now have reasonable hopes of retaining manynot all of their seats."The SNP, according to the poll, are doing even better in Holyrood voting intentions. The pro-independence party sits on %. That should deliver them  seats in the Scottish Parliament. Along with nine Greens, who will pick up nine seats, there would be a pro-independence majority in Holyrood after ,the polls hold as they are now.The polls also revealed that Brexit was by far the biggest issue of the election, with % of those surveyed citing leaving the EU as the most important issue. title: end-road-confirmed-stricken-glasgow-department-store
story: The retailer, which was established in , will disappear from the high street when its last remaining store is shut on December .The move follows the collapse of Watt Brothers into administration on October , after it succumbed to pressure on margins and the competition from online retailers amid the protracted downturn on the high street.:Watt Brothers latest: talks with interested parties continueWatt Brothersrsquo ten leasehold stores immediately closed, resulting in  of it  staff being made redundant, with the Sauchiehall Street store remaining open in a bid to clear remaining stock.Some  employees remain in post and will staff the store in its last days.Administrators Blair Nimmo and Alistair McAlinden at KPMG said this morning that discounts of up to  per cent would be applied to stock this week, before the store closes a week on Sunday.Mr Nimmo said: ldquoA substantial amount of stock has now been cleared and the remaining staff members continue to work tirelessly to clear all remaining items, with discounts of up to % now in place.ldquoI want to thank the staff for their efforts in supporting this challenging process.  employees remain at the store and wersquore working closely with Skills Development Scotland, via their PACE team, to support those who have been made redundant.The administrators said in October the retailer had been able to increase turnover year on year, with sales peaking at pound million in . However pressure on margins, sparked by the growth of online retailing and the broader downturn on the high street, dragged it into the red. An attempt to secure new investment proved to be unsuccessful.Talks with parties interested in acquiring the business and its assets continue, the administrators said.

title: tory-high-command-says-public-fed-tv-interviews-all-interviewer
story: Mr Neil, renowned for his forensic questioning, made an on-air plea to the Prime Minister after completing an interview with Nigel Farage, the Brexit Party leader, on Thursday night he has already quizzed Jeremy Corbyn and Jo Swinson.In a direct challenge to Mr Johnson, the Scot said: ldquoThere is no law, no Supreme Court ruling, that can force Mr Johnson to participate in a BBC leaders interview. But the Prime Minister of our nation will, at times, have to stand up to President Trump, President Putin, President Xi of China. So, it was surely not expecting too much that he spend half an hour standing up to me."The PM has also declined to be interviewed by ITVrsquos Julie Etchingham, who interviewed Mr Corbyn last night.However, this morning a senior Conservative source gave little hope the PM would comply with Mr Neilrsquos request, saying: ldquoThe public are fed up with interviews that are all about the interviewer and endless interruptions. The format is broken and needs to changeit is to start engaging and informing the public again."The PM will focus on talking to voters about peoples priorities including investing in our NHS and helping with the cost of living," he added.But Labourrsquos David Lammy hit back, tweeting: ldquoThe public is not fed up of interviews. Its fed up of being lied to. Boris Johnson ducking out of the leaders interviews is truly pathetic. He is breaking the publics trust yet again.On the stump in Kent, Mr Johnson was pressed on why he was avoiding an interview with Mr Neil and replied:"As I say, I think most people would say, Im the only prime minister to have done not one, but by tonight two head-to-head debates."Ive done  sitdown interviews with journalists, Ive fielded innumerable questions...we cannot accommodate everybody."Theres a guy called Lord Buckethead who wants to have a head-to-head debate with me. Unfortunately Im not able to fit him in. You know, we cant do absolutely everything," he added.

title: carlaw-denies-embarrassed-pm-omitting-speech

title: panto-review-goldilocks-three-bearsm-kings-edinburgh-four-stars
story: Goldilocks and the Three BearsKingrsquos Theatre, EdinburghMary Brennanfour starsldquoAhrsquove no been very weel...rsquo The audience roars with delight as Andy Gray tweaks his weel-kent catchphrase in a reference to his missing last yearrsquos panto due to ill health. The whole company are clearly glad hersquos back ndash they even make a song and dance about it, with ANDY writ large in big, glittery letters behind him. Best of all, hersquos fabulously on form: sending his voice looping from high to low on words that take his fancy ndash lsquoboxrsquo being one of them ndash while merrily slipping back into the bantering squabbles that have been a comedy mainstay of his relationship with Allan Stewartrsquos Auntie May.Hersquos playing the Ringmaster in her family circus ndash not that he gets to crack the whip. That falls to the wickedly cruel Baron who also has a circus, yoursquove probably guessed that the whipare wielded by Grant Stott, who roundly deserves the boos and hisses because of how he mistreats his animal acts .If itrsquos an entertaining pleasure to see Gray, Stewart and Stott reunited in tongue-twisting wordplay, and to welcome the affably doolally Jordan Young into the Edinburgh fold as Joey the Clown, the weak point comes with the plot-line itself.The old tale of Goldilocks and the Three Bears is made over into a story about rival circusses looking for a star attraction ndash cue three talking bears of child-pleasing furry cuteness, with Darren Brownlie especially adorable as the wriggly-squiggly dancing Baby Bear. The circus theme is bolstered by The Great Juggling Alfioand the Berserk Riders, a motorcycle stunt team. And mighty respect to Young who, for love of Goldilocks , walks the tightrope. As is the Qdos way, it is a lavishly dressed spectacle, but the real sparkle isnrsquot in sequins but in the performers ndash and luckily they shine.
